resources.string: If you enjoy this Blood Sugar, would \nyou mind rating us on the Google Play, then?
Easy to monitor and record your \nblood sugar.
Measure and analyze blood sugar levels \naccording to the sugar target range.
Control diabetes and manage health data.
This app needs permissions below to \nwork properly.
Invalid Date. Please select another date
You are adding a new record with the same content. Do you want to overwrite that record?
This time your blood sugar level is a bit low. Your safe range is 4.0–5.5, so please be careful.
1. When exercising: Check your blood sugar. Make sure you have snacks with you. Talk to your provider about reducing your insulin dose on days you exercise.
2. Control your bedtime: Snacks to prevent overnight low blood sugar. Protein-rich snacks may be best.
3. Don\'t drink alcohol without eating food: Women should limit alcohol consumption to 1 drink per day and men should limit alcohol consumption to 2 drinks per day.
Hello! Your blood sugar results this time are normal. I\'m happy to see your efforts pay off!

1. Eating: Enjoy your favorite foods in moderation. Your healthcare team can create a personalized meal plan. Focus on a variety of healthy foods from all groups: vegetables (both starchy and non-starchy), fruits, whole grains, lean proteins, and low-fat dairy. Incorporate heart-healthy fats from oils, nuts, seeds and fish. Use oil instead of butter or margarine when cooking.

2. Limit: Fried salty, and sugary foods and drinks, including sweets and beverages with added sugars. Choose water over sugary drinks and use sugar substitutes. Drink alcohol moderately and eat when consuming alcohol to prevent low blood sugar, especially if using insulin or certain diabetes medications.

3. Exercise: You can maintain a rhythmic activity, incorporating light activities every half hour when sitting for long periods of time. Aim for 30 minutes of aerobic exercise most days, such as brisk walking, swimming or cycling. Additionally, participate in strength training exercises 2–3 times per week to build muscle and increase calorie burning.
Unfortunately, your blood sugar level exceeds the standard range. Please try to control it within the range of 4.0–5.5.

1. Balanced diet: Focus on whole foods, emphasizing a diet rich in whole grains, lean proteins and healthy fats. Follow guidance from reputable sources such as the CDC and ADA regarding meal proportions. Limit sugary foods and drinks, and pay attention to portion sizes.

2. Regular physical activity: aiming for 150 minutes per week, can help prevent type 2 diabetes. Controlling your weight, getting enough sleep and avoiding too much alcohol and tobacco are also important. Monitoring A1C, blood pressure and cholesterol levels regularly is essential. With lifestyle modifications, prediabetes can be reversed, reducing the risk of developing diabetes.
Your blood sugar results are too high. Take control of it immediately
1. Food: Choose healthy foods and drinks, choosing dairy or plant-based alternatives, fruits, non-starchy vegetables, protein-rich foods and whole grains.
2. Nutrients: Prioritize nutrients such as vitamins, calcium, fiber and healthy fats. Pay attention to carbohydrates, especially in fruits, beans, and starchy vegetables.
3. Limit: Eat saturated fat, sodium, sugary foods and drinks. Drink alcohol in moderation and monitor your blood sugar levels, especially if taking insulin.

4. Meals: Discuss meal timing with healthcare professionals based on medications, activity level and health status. Consider carb counting or the plate-based eating method to manage portion sizes effectively.
5. Physical activity: Regular, gentle exercise helps people control diabetes and stay healthy.
When and how should I check my blood glucose?
What happens if my blood glucose level becomes too high?
How is hypoglycemia diagnosed in people without diabetes?
How can I prevent low blood sugar?

Blood glucose, also known as blood sugar, is the primary sugar present in your bloodstream, serving as the main source of energy for your body. It originates from the foods you consume, as most of the food you eat is broken down into glucose and released into your bloodstream. When your blood glucose levels rise, it triggers your pancreas to release insulin, a hormone responsible for facilitating the entry of glucose into your cells, where it is utilized for energy.

If you have diabetes, it's important to monitor your blood glucose regularly to ensure it stays within your target range. Depending on your specific situation, your healthcare team may advise you to check your blood glucose levels daily or even multiple times per day. 

The most common method for checking blood glucose at home is by using a blood glucose meter, which measures the glucose level in a small blood sample, typically obtained from your fingertip. 

Continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) is another option, where a small sensor is placed under your skin to continuously measure glucose levels throughout the day and night. CGM is particularly beneficial for individuals who use insulin and are at risk of low blood glucose levels. 

Additionally, your healthcare provider will conduct periodic blood tests called A1C tests to assess your average blood glucose levels over the past few months. People with diabetes usually undergo an A1C test at least twice a year, although more frequent testing may be necessary if treatment goals aren't being met.

High blood glucose, or hyperglycemia, manifests through symptoms like increased thirst, fatigue, headaches, frequent urination, and blurred vision. 

If you experience these symptoms regularly, discussing with your healthcare team is advisable. They may suggest adjustments to your diabetes management, such as changes in your meal plan, physical activity routine, or medication. 

Additionally, high blood glucose can result from other conditions affecting insulin or glucose levels, such as issues with the pancreas or adrenal glands.

Hypoglycemia is prevalent among individuals with diabetes, particularly those who rely on insulin for management. 

Research indicates that approximately 80% of people with Type 1 diabetes and nearly half of those with Type 2 diabetes who use insulin encounter at least one episode of low blood sugar within a four-week timeframe. Moreover, individuals with Type 2 diabetes who take oral medications like meglitinide or sulfonylurea also face an elevated risk of hypoglycemia. 

Although it's rare, hypoglycemia can occur in individuals without diabetes.

If your healthcare provider suspects hypoglycemia, they may conduct frequent blood sugar checks over several days of fasting to assess the condition. Additional tests may be required to identify the underlying cause of hypoglycemia, such as imaging studies to detect any tumors that may be responsible for the low blood sugar episodes. For reactive hypoglycemia, a mixed-meal tolerance test (MMTT) may be recommended. During this test, you will consume a special drink containing protein, fats, and sugar to stimulate blood glucose production and insulin release. Subsequently, your blood glucose levels will be monitored multiple times over a period of five hours to evaluate your body\'s response.

Preventing low blood sugar episodes in diabetes management can be challenging, but adjustments to your treatment plan can help minimize their occurrence. Understanding the triggers for low blood sugar is crucial, and providing detailed information to your healthcare provider about any episodes you experience is essential for effective management. 

To prevent low blood sugar: 

- Adhere to your medication regimen as prescribed. 

- Follow your healthcare provider's recommendations regarding diet and exercise. 

- Utilize continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) or regularly check your blood sugar levels, including before and after meals, exercise, and bedtime. 

- After treating a low blood sugar episode, document the details, including timing, recent food intake, exercise, symptoms experienced, and blood glucose level. This information can assist you and your provider in adjusting your management plan to prevent future occurrences.
